title: 103_hr3300
content:
The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act to promote wildlife conservation on military reservations. Integrated natural resource management plans are required for military installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with the Secretary having the discretion to determine if a plan is not appropriate for a specific installation. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with the Secretary having the discretion to determine if a plan is not appropriate for a specific installation. Amendments include changing references from "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan" throughout the text. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, replacing references to "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the text. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, replacing references to "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the text. Amendments include changing terminology in various sections to reflect this shift. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with changes including wetland protection and restoration, consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities, and the establishment of specific natural resource management goals, objectives, and time-frames. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, including wetland creation, conservation needs for biological communities, and specific resource management goals and objectives. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, addressing the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation. The plans ensure consistency among activities, no net loss in capability for military missions, sustained public use of natural resources, and necessary public access to installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, ensuring consistency among activities, no net loss in capability for military missions, sustained public use of natural resources, and necessary public access to installations. The Secretary of Defense shall provide public comment on these plans. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. The Secretary of Defense must provide an opportunity for public comment on each plan. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with the Secretary of Defense providing an opportunity for public comment on each plan. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States under their jurisdiction to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. A report on these determinations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 9 months, who will then report to Congress within 12 months. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 12 months listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not deemed appropriate, along with explanations for each. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not appropriate, along with explanations. Within 2 years, for installations not deemed inappropriate, a plan agreed upon by the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies must be prepared and implemented. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress listing military installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not appropriate. For installations where a plan is deemed appropriate, it must be mutually agreed upon by the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies and implemented within 2 years. The Secretary of Defense must negotiate with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies to make necessary changes to an integrated natural resource plan. Public comments are allowed on proposed plans and changes to cooperative plans. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is further amended by adding subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect, expenditure on conservation efforts, and other relevant details. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on integrated natural resource management plans, including the number of plans in effect, conservation expenditure, and compliance assessment with specific requirements. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on integrated natural resource management plans to ensure compliance with specific requirements, including no net loss of lands to support military missions. The Secretary of the Interior must also submit a report on conservation expenditure in consultation with State agencies responsible for conservation or wildlife management. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with State agencies, must report on conservation expenditure for integrated natural resource management plans to the Committees on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, Armed Services, and Environment and Public Works. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on natural resource conservation on military installations. SEC. 7 adds a new section for natural resource management services. SEC. 7 introduces a new section requiring each military department to have trained personnel for natural resource management services. SEC. 8 adds definitions to Title I. In Title I, "military department" refers to the Army, Navy, and Air Force. "Military installation" includes US-owned land managed by the Secretary of Defense or a military department. "State fish and wildlife agency" is a state government agency managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'United States' refers to States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and territories. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE.

Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'."

SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS.

(a) Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis".
(b) Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended to exclude section 1535 of that title.

SEC. 11. REPEAL.

Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed.

SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections, including section 101, 102, and 103 of the U.S.C. 670. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating the years for authorizations of appropriations to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997.
